msgSnippet: Cool!  I have to disagree with that the moral of my story is the importance of the IDE.  Sure, the right tool can make a job easier, but it wasnt THAT

Subject: RE: [junit] Re: awkward mock objects

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="windows-1252"
From: "Dinwiddie, George" <George.Dinwiddie@...>

Cool!  I have to disagree with that the moral of my story is
"the importance of the IDE."  Sure, the right tool can make a
job easier, but it wasnt' THAT difficult to type it in.  If I'd
been doing a lot of stuff like that, I'd have taken the javadoc
HTML and edited it with a more powerful editor (vi) than the
one I was using (Kawa 3.51a).  The job didn't seem big enough
to make that context switch.  It was just a PITA.

The reason I'm disagreeing is that I'm currently fighting VisualCafe
trying to get it to deploy a simple EJB to WebLogic.  I'm sure that
VisualCafe has a lot of power, but it also is quite complicate and
it hides what it's doing. (At least, it's not clear to me.)  Tools
that automate stuff for you are no substitute for knowing what's
going on.

That said, maybe I'll look into NetBeans.  I wonder if it'll be
fast enough to run on my lapton (a 233MHz K6)?

 - George

-----Original Message-----
From: Steve Freeman [mailto:steve@...]
Sent: Friday, March 16, 2001 3:23 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: awkward mock objects


I guess it's about time to announce our mock objects library at 
http://sourceforge.net/projects/mockobjects/. We aren't quite ready, 
largely because we haven't quite got the sourceforge infrastructure 
working for us, but it's in the CVS repository. There's no doc, but 
there are unit tests and a copy of our XP2000 paper.

The code includes our expectation library and mock implementations of 
things like io, servlets, and jdbc. There's also a jar that provides 
some fill-in classes so it can run in Java 1.1.x. Given it's raw 
state, please be gentle with us ;-) 

Interestingly, one of the morals of this exercise is the importance 
of the IDE. Creating mock objects from an interface is actually quite 
easy if you've got a tool, such as VisualAge or NetBeans, that will 
write the skeleton.

Steve

--- In junit@y..., "Dinwiddie, George" <George.Dinwiddie@a...> wrote:
> Speaking of mock objects, I needed to test some objects that 
initialized
> themselves from a JDBC ResultSet.  Rather than generate a test 
table and
> stuff data into it, I decided to create a MockResultSet.  Well, 
ResultSet is
> an interface with a LOT of methods.  What a boring chore this 
turned out to
> be.  In the end, I created an AbstractMockResultSet class that 
throws an
> SQLException for every method.  If anyone needs such a thing, let 
me know
> and it could save you a lot of typing.
